discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
Cisco DNA Spaces is a cloud-based location analytics platform that integrates with Cisco wireless infrastructure to provide real-time location insights and analytics.

For a successful implementation of Cisco DNA Spaces through a DNA Spaces Connector, the following requirements must be met:

(A) NMSP & SNMP Communication Between DNA Spaces Connector and WLC

The Cisco DNA Spaces Connector communicates with wireless controllers using the Network Mobility Services Protocol (NMSP) on TCP port 16113.
SNMP (UDP ports 161/162) is required for device status and telemetry data.
These ports must be open and accessible between the WLC and the DNA Spaces Connector.
(B) Cloud Connectivity to DNA Spaces

The DNA Spaces Connector must have internet access to reach the cloud service at https://connector.dnaspaces.io.
This is critical for data exchange between the on-premises infrastructure and Cisco DNA Spaces.

comments.content:
A. Cisco DNA Spaces Connector must connect to the wireless controllers on NMSP port 16113 over TCP and SNMP ports 161/162 over UDP:

While NMSP (Network Mobility Services Protocol) and SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) are used in some Cisco location-based services, they are not required for DNA Spaces. DNA Spaces primarily uses the wireless controller API for data collection.

C. The wireless controllers must enable Cisco CMX Connector:

Cisco CMX (Connected Mobile Experiences) is a separate product and is not required for DNA Spaces. DNA Spaces uses its own connector and cloud platform.

E. Cisco DNA Space Connector must be able to connect to the wireless network via CAPWAP ports 5246 and 5247:

CAPWAP (Control and Provisioning of Wireless Access Points) ports are used for communication between APs and the wireless controller, not for the DNA Spaces Connector.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
To enable location services using Cisco DNA Spaces through a DNA Spaces Connector, the following requirements are mandatory:

B. Cisco DNA Space Connector must be able to reach out to https://connector.dnaspaces.io:

The DNA Spaces Connector must have internet connectivity to communicate with the Cisco DNA Spaces cloud platform. This is essential for syncing data and receiving configuration updates.

D. Ensure that the wireless controller API is accessible for the DNA Space Connector:

The DNA Spaces Connector interacts with the wireless controller via its API to collect location data (e.g., RSSI values from clients and APs). The API must be accessible for the connector to function properly.

Selected Answer: AB
Both SNMP & NMSP are required..

questions.question_text: An engineer must enable location services using Cisco DNA Space through a DNA Space Connector on a client located in the US. Which two requirements are mandatory for a successful implementation? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Ensure that the wireless controller API is accessible for the DNA Space Connector.
choices.A: Cisco DNA Spaces Connector must connect to the wireless controllers on NMSP port 16113 over TCP and SNMP ports 161/162 over UDP.
choices.E: Cisco DNA Space Connector must be able to connect to the wireless network via CAPWAP ports 5246 and 5247.
choices.B: Cisco DNA Space Connector must be able to reach out to https://connector.dnaspaces.io
choices.C: The wireless controllers must enable Cisco CMX Connector.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
When configuring an ACL on a Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) to control IPv4 traffic to the CPU, the ACL must be applied in the inbound direction. Here's why:

Inbound ACL:

An inbound ACL filters traffic entering the WLC's CPU. This is the correct direction to control traffic that is destined for the CPU, such as management traffic, control traffic, or other packets that the CPU needs to process.

Applying the ACL in the inbound direction ensures that unwanted or malicious traffic is filtered before it reaches the CPU, protecting the controller from potential attacks or resource exhaustion.

Outbound ACL:

An outbound ACL filters traffic leaving the WLC's CPU. This is not relevant for controlling traffic destined for the CPU.

None/Any:

These options are not valid for applying an ACL to control CPU traffic. The ACL must be explicitly applied in the inbound direction.

questions.question_text: An engineer configures an ACL on a Cisco WLC v8.7. The engineer must control IPv4 traffic to the CPU of the controller. The engineer updates the ACL via the GUI and has to define the direction in which the ACL must be applied. Which value should be applied to the direction option?

comments.content:
Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
Option A: Set to Rule Type “Email”, Notify “All”, and include condition “RSSI” with a value of “–65 dBm.”

The Rule Type cannot be set to “Email.” The Rule Type should be “Malicious” to classify the rogue AP as a threat.

Option B: Set to Rule Type “Malicious,” Notify “All”, and include condition “RSSI” with a value of “–65 dBm.”

The Notify option should be set to “Email” to ensure that email notifications are sent. “All” is not a valid option for notifications.

Option D: Set to Rule Type “Malicious,” Notify “Enabled”, and include condition “RSSI” with a value of –65 dBm.”

The Notify option should be set to “Email” to enable email notifications. “Enabled” is not a valid option for notifications.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
To configure Cisco Prime Infrastructure to send an email notification when a rogue AP with a signal strength stronger than -65 dBm is detected, the following rule configuration must be used:

Rule Type:

Set to “Malicious” to classify the rogue AP as a potential threat.

Notify:

Set to “Email” to ensure that email notifications are sent when the rule is triggered.

Condition:

Include the condition “RSSI” with a value of “–65 dBm” to specify that only rogue APs with a signal strength stronger than -65 dBm trigger the notification.

choices.D: Set to Rule Type “Malicious,” Notify “Enabled”, and include condition “RSSI” with a value of –65 dBm.”
choices.B: Set to Rule Type “Malicious,” Notify “All”, and include condition “RSSI” with a value of “–65 dBm.”
choices.A: Set to Rule Type “Email”, Notify “All”, and include condition “RSSI” with a value of “–65 dBm.”
choices.C: Set to Rule Type “Malicious,” Notify “Email”, and include condition “RSSI” with a value of “–65 dBm.”

questions.question_text: A network administrator wants to receive an email notification whenever their wireless network detects a rogue AP that is stronger than -65 dBm. To accomplish this, Cisco Prime Infrastructure must be used to create and install configuration templates that establish a rogue AP rule. Which rule configuration must be used?
An IT administrator is managing a wireless network in which most devices are Apple iOS. A QoS issue must be addressed on the WLANs. Which configuration must be performed?

choices.D: Enable WMM TSPEC/TCLAS negotiation under Wireless > Advanced.
choices.B: Create a new AVC Profile named AUTOQOS-AVC-PROFILE and apply to all WLANs.
choices.A: Enable Fastlane globally under Wireless > Access Points > Global Configuration.
choices.C: Enable Fastlane under each WLAN setting.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
On 9800 Controller
tags/profiles->wlan->SSID->advanced tab->Fastlane

Selected Answer: C
For a wireless network with mostly Apple iOS devices, Fastlane is the recommended configuration to address QoS issues. Fastlane is a Cisco feature designed to optimize the performance of Apple devices on wireless networks by ensuring proper QoS handling. Here’s why:

Fastlane:
Fastlane combines Wi-Fi Multimedia (WMM) and AVC (Application Visibility and Control) to prioritize traffic for Apple devices. It ensures that voice, video, and other real-time traffic from Apple devices receive the appropriate QoS treatment.

Configuration:
Fastlane must be enabled under each WLAN setting to ensure that the QoS policies are applied to the traffic on that WLAN. This ensures consistent performance for Apple iOS devices across the network.

Why not the other options?
A. Enable Fastlane globally under Wireless > Access Points > Global Configuration:
Fastlane is not enabled globally; it must be configured on a per-WLAN basis to ensure proper QoS handling for Apple devices.

Selected Answer: A
You can only enable Fastlane per WLAN. 
The Global Setting is just to reset Fastlane to its default parameters
--> Answer A

comments.content:
Never mind, Fastlane can onlt be enabled on a per-WLAN basis, https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/wireless/access_point/9130ax/tech-notes/fastlane-faq.pdf
Correct answer is C

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Why enable each indvidual WLAN when you can enable it globally?
Enabling Fastlane globally under the WLC's Wireless > Access Points > Global Configuration settings allows Fastlane to be applied to all WLANs on the network. 
While C is technically correct, the best answer is A.
Enable FT on WLAN automatically enable FT globally

questions.question_text: An engineer must configure client profiling on a Cisco WLC v8.2 and a Cisco ISE. The customer has a complex wireless network with different AP modes, depending on locations and functionalities. Which two AP modes should be configured for full functionality? (Choose two.)

comments.content:
Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
B. Workgroup Bridge:

Workgroup Bridge (WGB) mode is used to connect wired devices to a wireless network. It does not support client profiling because the WGB itself is treated as a single client, and individual wired devices behind it are not profiled.

C. Standalone:

In Standalone Mode, APs operate independently without a WLC. Since client profiling relies on the WLC to analyze traffic, this mode does not support profiling.

D. Local Authentication:

Local Authentication refers to the authentication method used by APs in FlexConnect mode. It is not an AP mode and does not directly impact client profiling.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
To enable client profiling on a Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) v8.2 and Cisco ISE, the following AP modes should be configured for full functionality:

Local Mode:

In Local Mode, APs forward all client traffic to the WLC for processing. This mode is essential for client profiling because the WLC can analyze and profile client traffic before forwarding it to the network.

FlexConnect Mode:

In FlexConnect Mode, APs can operate in a hybrid manner, forwarding traffic locally or to the WLC depending on the configuration. FlexConnect APs can still support client profiling by sending client data to the WLC for analysis, even when operating in standalone mode.
